title: Will the United Socialist Party of Venezuela (PSUV) maintain its majority in Venezuela's National Assembly after the next legislative elections?
preds: Venezuelans to Vote in Polls Seen Handing Congress to Opposition

This question is unanswerable. Everyone and their cousin knows the psuv will not retain the national assembly. I however beleive that the regime will impose its majority irregardless of pety things such as popular will. 
I beleive the spirit of the question is will the Venezuelan opposition garner enough support to win a majority of the parliament. My answer is yes. I do not beleive the dictatorship will recognise the election as a result. What comes next I do not know.

Let's consider the ways PSUV might win
-the polls are wrong.  pollsters have traditionally underestimated electoral support for Chavismo
-PSUV has for years demonstrated an ability to mobilize its voters
-government intimidation of opposition
-7 opposition leaders have been banned from running for office
-4 opposition leaders are imprisoned. 
-electoral fraud:  no qualified electoral observation from the OAS or EU
-gerrymandered districts so that 52% of voters, in pro-opposition urban areas, elect just 39% of parliament,
-The electoral map is set up to dilute opposition ballots. So while a candidate in a pro-government district might win a spot with 10,000 votes, a rival in an opposition stronghold might need 350,000 votes to win the seat. “It’s not enough just to win,” León said. “You have to double the votes that your adversary might get.” As a result “the opposition might be a clear majority but may control Congress by a narrow margin,” 
-fake parties with names mimicking legitimate opposition parties to confuse voters.
-government-imposed state of emergency in swing states in the west prevents opposition campaigning
-refusal to renew broadcasting licenses to opposition media
-the low-cost food program swayed voters
-continuing affection for Chavez
 -doing “whatever it takes.” Venezuelans understand exactly what he means.

Several factors most likely will determine the outcome.   Political patronage (Colectivos) at community and ellite levels in the government, the control of the National Electoral Commission, high polling numbers for the opposition in certain areas in the country - it does not accurately reflect a national level of polling, Maduro's stated intent to move the Venezuela to civilian-military rule (if it looses a majority to the opposition) and a single electoral observer that is tightly connected to and approves the Venezuelan political system and it's status quo.

Probably my last before the poll itself, barring something unexpected happening. There are four sources I'm considering: 
1) The projection of the opinion polls, adjusted according to historical opposition underpolling and the skew of the electoral system to rural votes. This projects that PSUV will have 35% of the seats in the National Assembly (MUD should have 46%). So that's a pretty emphatic loss of control. I'm weighting this 60%.
2) Turnout for Primaries - PSUV's turnout was twice that of MUD. Using this as a proxy for grassroots strength, that suggests PSUV will keep control. I'm weighting this 20%.
3) A referendum on the government/status quo. I spotted this link on another prediction (it was a link from the article linked to by @Dima K), but basically if you plug the current "positivity" rating (12%) into the tool, you end up with similar numbers to the adjusted opinion polling projection (36% for PSUV). To be honest, I'm not convinced - it worked well in 2010, but there are lots of explanations that suggest correlation and not causation. Still, I'm weighting this 10%.
4) The chance of the poll being stolen/disrupted. I was inclined to ignore this, as it felt like 3rd world/populist snobbery, but there have been some signs (helpfully pointed out by @vox vox) that there have been more than usual shenanigans around dodgy electoral practices. Based upon what I've read, while I think there will be some dodginess, I think there is only a 30% chance this could determine the poll.  I'm weighting this 10%.

Datanalisis reports the opposition maintains a 30 percent lead over the ruling party, and Bloomberg projection that Manduro is heading for a fall, and anecdotal perceptions relative to the change in Argentina, I would suggest (at risk of being incorrect) that the rootedness of the Party, the particular brand of Chaves-Maduro socialism, instrumental control by the party over its political and institutional structure, and the stated motivation to maintain its power over the state 'by any means necessary," we should not underestimate a critical dynamic on Venezuelan politics:  elections are not about political representation and the 'leveling' of society by socialism, it is rather about the ability to exercise and control power by the party itself (a central tenet of all political parties historically who have ruled in the name of socialist equality).  While the economic and political conditions of the populace are a serious matter of concern and should not be dismissed, I am not sure that society is able to overcome the collective action problem posed by state elites.

Mark Weisbrot of the Center for Economic and Policy Research has a post up on The Huffington Post about the recent electoral history in Venezuela, and the allegations of electoral fraud. (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mark-weisbrot/venezuela-election-us_b_8554750.html) He concludes: "Hence the pre-emptive strike to discredit the elections: If [the opposition forces] do worse than they expect to do, they will claim fraud. And the hardliners, at least, will continue on their extra-constitutional path towards regime change. This has been -- with U.S. support -- plan B (and sometimes plan A) for most of the past 16 years, despite the fact that there has not been a shred of credible evidence of electoral fraud during that entire period."

I suppose that depends on what "after" means. Maduro has said that the revolution will win "como sea" â€” "by hook or by crook." Maduro and PSUV have already done a bit of gerrymandering to favor the PSUV. If "como sea" means that the PSUV will not recognize unfavorable results, and by some maneuver, retain its seats or seat its candidates regardless of the results, then yes, there is a high probability that it will retain its majority. If it means that the tallied results show that it didn't retain its majority, then likely no, but almost certainly Maduro and the PSUV will try to annul those results. Whether he can muster enough force to do that is an open question; he doesn't have the popular support, though. Current opinion polls have the opposition MUD leading PSUV ~50% to ~30%, so I'm translating that proportionally to a 27% yes for PSUV keeping their majority. However, the PSUV "ground game" can't be ignored - their primary turnout was twice that of the opposition. So if that translates effectively to a 66% poll in favour of PSUV, the mean of the two is 46%.

Is stealing an election even worthwhile at this point? It seems like the tide of public opinion isn't going to be easy to reverse with the resources they have on hand, and those poll numbers haven't been moving much in the last few months. In a perfect world, I'd grab some reference-class "elections that were expected to unseat powerful parties in semi-democracies" and check out what actually happened compared to polling data. But for now, I'm mostly in on la revolucion. (Still slightly in on "the world is not very exciting" and "political machines can do a lot of work", though.)
Although Maduro isn't even a worst copy of Chavez, he is the leader of such contructed machine that opposition almost cannot win (at least not during this elections).

Maduro doesn't have the populist charisma the Chavez had, the population is fatigued of the PSUV, and petroleum income is down.  Still, Chavez did build an effective political machine that could still pull off a majority.
There's just so much people can take before taking action.
Unless there's a total collapse of the system, like a revolution, they'll still be a majority by the PSUV.

The collapse in forex reserves, depreciation against the USD in "real" terms (as opposed to the official forex rates), low oil prices, high inflation would imply that there should be a change in the guard. However, Maduro has gone on record as saying the election will be won "No matter what", and that is no idle threat in Venezuela. I nevertheless think PSUV will lose elections but will use the military to stay in power.

They've been running a quasi-authoritarian regime with populist policies/rhetoric. This gets them the vote of a lot of poor people. On the other hand, they've been in power for sufficiently long that the voters may be fatiguing of them. I think they have the (slight) advantage but will update when I look into this more.

Polling is traditionally biased to favor PSUV (e.g., see 2013 and 2010 elections). That MUD leads by two digits number in polls aggregate is quite telling. Vote rigging concerns are overblown - Venezuela is NOT Afghanistan. There will be fraud but it cannot be the scale required. Plus, Maduro is kind of a dimwit, so he is likely to not have made the right choices to ensure his party's success. And "the economy, stupid".
It depends if elections and free and fair.

There is good evidence on both sides of this debate. I think vote rigging will occur and fear will rule the electorate. I'm very tempted to go in the middle on this one, because on the other hand polls show that people want change, the economy has been mismanaged, and Maduro is not a popular figure. Still, the likelihood a dictator will stay in power another year is usually quite high, on the other hand systems where there is semi-democratic rule are inherently unstable and instability could tip that especially given the recent chaos. Difficult to find a good driver, especially when as an outsider you think that a dictator is not good which gives you an inherent bias against seeing him stay in power.

Maduro lacks the charisma and appeal of Chavez, and it's hard to drum up support when grocery stores look like this (http://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2015/10/29/452636462/the-nightmare-of-grocery-shopping-in-venezuela). In a more open society, the odds are good that the PSUV lose power, and the polls support this (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venezuelan_parliamentary_election,_2015).
expect massive fraud and disqualifications of any candidates that have a reasonable chance of unseating PSUV candidates.

The economic situation of Venezuela actually negatively affects the chance of PSUV to keep the majority. An increase in the black market exchange rate in Venezuela to 1000 bolivares per dollar would secure a majority vote for the opposition.

Initial forecast. I have spent some time in Venezuela, and all that I have to add is to never underestimate the ability of whatever party/junta/dictator that may rule at any given time to maintain their position and power. I might add that the government buildings in downtown Caracas still are pock-marked from the bullets that announced the initial arrival of Hugo Chavez in 1992. The situation in the country is so dire that I cannot give it a probability of 100 percent, but will go with my usual adverse non-zero base rate of p = 0.18.
Yes, observers kicked out, people leaving their country for Miami... nothing gonna change this year.

Current polls give the opposition Democratic Unity Roundtable a sizeable lead of around 60%, versus 30% for PSV (see [1]).  Opinion polls in Venezuela are obviously less reliable than elsewhere.  However, the polls did a reasonable job of estimating opposition support in the last election (see [2]).  The current government seems to be genuinely unpopular, and it would take very large-scale vote-rigging for them to keep their majority.

If this were an actual election in a real country, PSUV would be out.  However, lots of opposition leaders are in jail, and there's plenty of room in the jails for more--and that's before the press muzzling and beatings and other campaign tactics of one of the more thuggish political parties currently at large.  It will be closer than they'd prefer, but they should retain the majority. Stay tuned, though--the world is full of surprises.
Election observers chased out... says enough for me

The potential for fixing the election to a majority is high through intimidation and arrest, but discontent against super-inflation and other elements and will cause a notification of a majority, but not fully sustainable. The result will be a minority majority scenario.
